en.comp:
Read the passage given below and answer the questions complete the statements that follow by choosing the correct options from the given ones.

1. India experienced a 15% drop in fresh Covid - 19 cases detected in the week ending Sunday, the lowest weekly count in more than six months with Kerala numbers declining by a steep 21%. The country reported over 2.14 lakh new cases in the week (September 13-19), down from 2.51 lakh in the previous seven days. This was the lowest numbers of cases reported in 27 weeks since March 8-14 (for weeks ending Sunday).

2. The sharp fall in all India infections was mainly due to numbers dropping in Kerala, which still accounts for 62% of all cases in the country during this week. Two weeks earlier, Kerala's weekly case count had crossed 2 lakhs, as the latest wave of the pandemic in the state peaked; cases continued to decline in Maharashtra while Mizoram and Tamil Nadu registered a rise in infections during the week.

3. Meanwhile, on Sunday, India reported 30,814 fresh cases, nearly the same as the number on the previous day (31,242) as Kerala logged 19,653 new infections. The state had recorded 19,352 cases the previous day.

4. There were 295 deaths from the virus with Kerala reporting 152 fatalities, Maharashtra 49, Tamil Nadu 27, Karnataka 16 and Bengal 11.

en.value: <p>What does the phrase &#39;mimic fleets&#39; mean in the poem?</p>
en.comp:
Read the extract given below and answer the questions that follow by selecting the correct/most appropriate options:

From the neighbouring school come the boys,
And down the wet streets
Sail the mimic fleets,
Till the treacherous pool
Engulfs them in its whirling and turbulent ocean.
In the country, on every side,
Where far and wide,
Like a leopard's tawny and spotted hide,
Stretches the plain,
How welcome the plain,
How welcome is the rain!

The writers fantasy was to have a reunion with her friends
en.comp:
Read the passage given below and answer the questions/complete the statements that follow by choosing the correct options from the given ones.

So, finally, after many months of breathless anticipation one of my fantasies came true. I finally managed to meet my girlfriends-in person no less-for coffee. All three of us had been double-jabbed, the requisite waiting period for immunity to kick in was over and we had been adhering to social distancing norms like our lives depend on it. So as the case load in Delhi fell to under 200 daily cases and the positivity rate went below one percent, we decided that it was time we threw caution and our masks-to the wind and finally met up for a cup of coffee.

That said, we were still wary enough not to risk congregating in a place full of unmasked strangers. So, we opted to meet at the home of one of us, sitting in an airy, well-ventilated room, which looked out on a verdant lawn, exchanging elbow bumps rather than hugs as a concession to virus. In the event, it was too hot a morning for coffee, so all three of us chose to have nimbu pani instead, loaded with lots of ice and a divine hint of kala namak (salt).

As we quaffed our drinks and exchanged gossip, often talking over one another in our excitement to finally be together, we finally feel that life was returning to normal-or, at least to be a semblance of normalcy. Don't get me wrong. We had been zooming one another regularly all through the pandemic so it wasn't as if we had lost touch.

So as the case load in Delhi fell to under 200 daily cases and the positivity rate went below one percent, we decided that it was time we threw caution and our masks-to the wind and finally met up for a cup of coffee.

That said, we were still wary enough not to risk congregating in a place full of unmasked strangers. So, we opted to meet at the home of one of us, sitting in an airy, well-ventilated room, which looked out on a verdant lawn, exchanging elbow bumps rather than hugs as a concession to virus. In the event, it was too hot a morning for coffee, so all three of us chose to have nimbu pani instead, loaded with lots of ice and a divine hint of kala namak (salt).

As we quaffed our drinks and exchanged gossip, often talking over one another in our excitement to finally be together, we finally feel that life was returning to normal-or, at least to be a semblance of normalcy. Don't get me wrong. We had been zooming one another regularly all through the pandemic so it wasn't as if we had lost touch.

en.value: Choose the correct statement :
en.comp:
Read the passage given below and answer the questions/complete the statements that follow with the help of given options.

1. In my mother's home everything necessary for our daily consumption was produced at their farm itself. Mangoes bananas, coconut, jackfruit, apply, beans, eggs, chicken, cashewnut, milk, paper etc were available free of cost and in huge quantities. All the processed food like rice powder and Kerala-specific snacks that line the shelves of bakeries today were painstakingly prepared at home.

2. There were only a few things that my grandpa used to purchase from Vellu Chetan's shop : lentils, potatoes, tomatoes, cola and jaggery. The other main shopping was from one or two shops in the nearest town which supplied material for men's shirts and the blouse, number and shawl for women of our community. Very little paper money was required for these purposes.

3. The economy was literally a cashless economy. I remember my grandpa used to walk miles to visit relations/friends. There were very few buses or other automobiles in these days. What is truly amazing is that a great change has occurred within a short span of twenty years.

4. Undoubtedly, all of us are beneficiaries of a growing economy but we are at a crossroads where development vs. growths paradox is constantly being debated. Talks on adulterated food and their adverse impact on health have covered the media headlines. I am a proud cashless customer who uses credit cards debit cards etc. for payments. With a whole lot of cashless options before me, I first purchase and purchase.... without realising that at this rate it could literally make me cashless!

options.value: Rice powder was pounded at home and sold to the bakeries.
Milk and pepper were got free from the market.
Family could not eat all of the mangoes and bananas.
Potatoes and Tomatoes were not grown at their farm.

teachers understanding of how children learn

options.value: how a learner uses the language
processes of the inputs by the learner
aspects of grammar, use of vocabulary, pronunciation etc.

options.value: learning the rules of grammar and reproduce it later.

Collaborative activity as group work and convert into individual work.
